itemDescription: George Cross recipient in World War II

wikipedia_page.main: Richard Valentine Moore,  (14 February 1916 – 25 April 2003), known as Dick Moore, was an officer of Royal Naval Volunteer Reserve who was awarded the George Cross for the "great gallantry and undaunted devotion to duty" he showed in rendering mines safe during the Blitz of 1940 despite having "no practical training".

response: * Dick Moore (Royal Navy officer) (1916–2003), British Royal Navy officer awarded the George Cross in World War II
** Dick Moore, World War II naval officer and George Cross recipient (born 1916)

He was posthumously awarded the George Cross for the "great gallantry and undaunted devotion to duty" he displayed while attempting to defuse a parachute mine that had fallen in Dagenham, Essex, during the Blitz, along with Lieutenant Commander Richard John Hammersley Ryan and Dick Moore. Notice of his award appeared in a supplement to the London Gazette of 17 December 1940.The George Cross at Sea, 1939–45
*Dick Moore, 87, British Royal Naval officer and recipient of the  George Cross.
